title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: " M'Govan—I want M'Govan," he wearily whispered, andthen the man gave him to understand that the hour was late,and that I had gone home long since. Then, as he still repeated his whisper, the man directed him to my house inCharles Street, and he turned away in that direction. Hefound Charles Street, but had no idea where the house was.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Then, as he still repeated his whisper, the man directed him to my house inCharles Street, and he turned away in that direction. Hefound Charles Street, but had no idea where the house was. He had looked for some kind of big, wide entrance, like thatat the Central.

title: The Red Room
author: Le Queux, William
snippet: Having lit a cigarette the doctor strolled down the Haymarket, andturning up Charles Street, passed the "Junior," crossed St. James'sSquare, where he entered the "Sports," made inquiry for someone, butfound the person was hot in. Then, continuing his way--while I walkedat a respectable distance behind--he turned into Duke Street, where at adoor about half-way up he paused and tugged at a bell.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: Francis Jeffrey was born in the four-storied house No. 7 Charles Street, which has known no change. In i8oi he began his married  life on the third floor of No. i8 Buccleuch Place, one of a row of plain three-storied houses standing now on a broad, quiet street, two or three hundred yards long, roughly paved with round cobble-stones, between which the grass forces its way in almost rural luxuriance.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence

title: Traced and Tracked; or, Memoirs of a City Detective, etc
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: " Give me the man's address, and I'llgo to him myself." They ought to have given him M'Sweeny's address, considering the hour and the work I had done the day before, butthey didn't; they gave him mine ; and out to Charles Streethe came at half-past four in the morning, and roused me out ofbed, sleepy, stupid, and dazed with having got only three hoursrest instead of eight, and, without waiting to see if I understoodhim, at once began to bemoan his loss.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: At the corner of Charles Street I paused to administer my topographical tit-for-tat.

author: Hutton, Laurence
